text: Gallery: Kalamazoo mass shooting victims KALAMAZOO, MI -- A memorial service will be held at noon a.m. Saturday, Feb. 27 at Immanuel Lutheran Church, 9650 N. Church Street, Bridgman for Mary Lou Nye, 62, who was killed in Kalamazoo. A daycare worker known as "Miss Mary" to her charges was one of six people gunned down by a suspect in the Saturday, Feb. 20 mass shooting in Kalamazoo. She was with friends, including her sister-in-law Mary Jo Nye, when the group of women was attacked in the parking lot of the Cracker Barrel restaurant on 9th Street near I-94. The four women died in the attack; teenaged girl with them survives in critical condition. Mary Lou's daughter-in-law, Gwen Marchant-Nye, the wife of her son Bart Nye, talked about how his father was trying to hold up. "The person who would've been best suited to help him get through the loss of his wife would be his sister, and the person who could have helped most with the death of his sister died in the car next to her, Gwen Marchant-Nye said. " Losing his wife and sister both at once is a hard blow." Bart Nye is a manager at Noodles and Company and lives with his family in Ray, Mich. He has made the 7-hour trip to Baroda and back to be with his dad every day since the shootings, with the exception of yesterday, when weather prohibited the trip, she said. This week, Bart brought back a bunch of Christmas presents he discovered that Mary Lou had bought for her young grandson. Mary Lou Nye was born on September 5, 1953 in Lansing, the daughter of the late Raymond and Hazel (Smith) McCarrick, according to her obituary on the Pike Funeral Home website. In, 1975, she married Christopher C. Nye, who survives. Nye retired after 30 years working for the Michigan Secretary of State in several positions, and retired as the assistant manager of the Benton Harbor office. For the past five years she had worked for the Immanuel Lutheran Church's Day Care Center in Bridgman. Survivors include her husband; son, Bart (Gwen) Nye of Ray Twp., Mich.; grandson Geoffrey Nye; siblings Roseleah Paradis of Clinton Twp., Mich., Joan Demorest of Republic, Mich., and Sue McCarrick. She was preceded in death by son Jonathan Nye in 1991 and a brother, Herbert McCarrick. Friends may meet with the family on Saturday at the church beginning at 10 a.m. until the time of the service. Nye served in the United States Air Force Reserve for 10 years, and will be buried in Fort Custer National Cemetery in Battle Creek. Memorial contributions may be given to Immanuel Lutheran Church Day Care, PO Box 26, Bridgman, MI 49106. To learn more about a fund to help with funeral expenses, click here. Rosemary Parker is a reporter for MLive. Contact her at rparker3@mlive.com. Note to readers: if you purchase something through one of our affiliate links we may earn a commission. text: Gallery: Kalamazoo mass shooting victims Mary Jo Nye, a retired teacher, was one of six people killed in a shooting spree on Saturday, Feb. 20, 2016 in Kalamazoo. BATTLE CREEK, MI -- Friends will gather Sunday, Feb. 28 in memory of Mary Jo Nye, 60, who described herself as "everyone's cheerleader." Nye was one of six people killed in a mass shooting in Kalamazoo Saturday, Feb. 20. Her sister-in-law Mary Lou Nye, with her and friends on an outing, was also killed in the shooting. A memorial service for Mary Jo Nye will be held at Chapel Hill United Methodist Church in Battle Creek at 3 p.m., with a light meal and fellowship to follow, according to the obituary posted on the funeral home website. Mary Jo Nye was born the sixth of seven children to Charles Manley and Joan (Cushing) on Aug. 14, 1955. She was raised on the family farm in Baroda where she learned how to cook and sew from her mother and grandmother. A graduate of Lakeshore High School, she attended Western Michigan University and Michigan State University, where she studied primary education. She spent her early career establishing an adult literacy program in Southwest Michigan and went on to be president of the Literacy Council of Calhoun County. She also worked with the Humane Society and The Haven of Rest of Battle Creek. Nye was a founding teacher of Calhoun Community High School, an alternative education high school in Battle Creek, where she helped and mentored students. She was an active member of the United Methodist Church, a member of the Chapel Hill Methodist Church's human resources committee. Nye is survived by her father Charles, her brothers and sisters Vicki (Stan) Nitz, Dave, Tim (Jacalyn), Chris, Julia (Byron) Miller, and Kerry, and numerous nieces, nephews, close friends, mentees, and students. She was preceded in death by her mother Joan, sister-in-law Sandie, and nephew Jon. Services are being handled by Pike Funeral Home, Boyd Chapel, 9191 Red Arrow Highway, Bridgman. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial donations for Mary Jo Nye be sent to Chapel Hill United Methodist Church, 157 Chapel Hill Drive, Battle Creek, MI 49015. text: Gallery: Kalamazoo mass shooting victims Judy Brown BATTLE CREEK, MI -- A private funeral service for Dorothy "Judy" Brown, 74, killed by a gunman on a rampage in Kalamazoo last weekend, will be Friday but not at her church as originally announced. Because the family hopes to keep the service as private as possible, family and friends will be notified of the location, according to her pastor. No visitation is planned. Marian and Art Herriman said they plan to drive down from their Upper Peninsula home near Manistique to attend services for Brown, who has been Marian Herriman's friend since 4th grade. "She was one of the most caring people I knew," Marian Herriman said. An employee of Guardian Finance and Advocacy Services until her retirement a year ago, Brown was dedicated to helping her clients with their legal and financial work, often making house calls on weekends if they needed help, Herriman said. "She was just so conscientious," she said. Herriman said she and Brown had grown up as friends whose parents had neighboring lake cottages in Calhoun County. They attended Hillsdale College together, stood in each other's weddings and both named their sons Jeffrey Scott. "Judy was just up here in the UP few moths ago and went to church with us," Art Herriman said. She loved Northern Michigan, so much that she had been considering a move to the small town of Onekama in the Northern Lower Peninsula, he said. The Herrimans learned of the Kalamazoo shootings while in church Sunday morning, when a visiting exchange student got a call from worried family in Frankfurt, Germany, who had heard of the tragedy. "That's the first we heard about it. As soon as we got home, my wife had gotten a call from Judy's cousin, and was just starting to call her back when another friend called with the news," Art Herriman said. Brown was with a group of friends in the parking lot of the Cracker Barrel restaurant near I-94 and 9th Street west of Kalamazoo, where they had gone following a theatrical event, when they were shot at 10:24 p.m. Saturday, Feb. 20. Brown and three other women were killed and a 14-year-old girl was critically injured. Just minutes before that, alleged gunman Jason B. Dalton had shot and killed a father and son at a Kalamazoo car dealership and hours before that shot and wounded a woman at an apartment complex east of Kalamazoo, authorities say. Dorothy J. Knight "Judy" Brown was born in Battle Creek, attended Hillsdale College and graduated with a bachelor's degree from Western Michigan University, according to the obituary on the funeral home's web site. While in college she married Edwin Reynolds, and after divorcing she later married Curtis Brown and moved to Nashville, Ind., where she lived for the next 25 years. After moving back to Battle Creek, she worked as a caseworker for the Area Agency on Aging at Burnham Brook, and also for Guardian Finance and Advocacy. Surviving are her children Jeff Reynolds and husband, Lorenzo of California and Rob Reynolds of Florida; brother, Bob Knight; sister-in-law, Betty Knight; nieces, nephews, granddaughter and great grandchildren. She was preceded in death by her parents, George Clinton Knight and Dorothy (Putney) Knight, founders of the former Knight's Appliances, and a brother, George Knight. Rev. Ann Ashby, pastor of the Unity of Battle Creek church, where Brown was a member, said Brown and Barbara Hawthorne, another church member who was also killed in the Feb. 20 shootings, were friends who will be sorely missed by the community. "Both are loving, caring, always of service to everyone around the," Ashby said. "I know they have been friends for a long time, and are part of a group of women who have spent a lot of time together in craft meetings, attending movies, and doing all sorts of thing to enjoy life." Their deaths, she said, "were very sad unexpected and shocking for all of us." In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in Brown's honor may be directed to the Humane Society of South Central Michigan, 2500 Watkins Road, Battle Creek, MI 49015 or the Bronson @ Home Hospice, 165 Washington Ave., Battle Creek, MI 49037. The Farley Estes Dowdle Funeral Home & Cremation Care, Battle Creek is handling arrangements. Rosemary Parker is a reporter for MLive. Contact her at rparker3@mlive.com. text: Abigail Kopf Shooting spree victim Abigail Kopf, 14, remained in critical condition Monday, Feb. 22, at Bronson Methodist Hospital. She is shown with shooting victim Barbara Hawthorne, whom she called Grandma Barb. Hawthorne was among those who died Saturday night.- Courtesy of The Kopf family. (Courtesy of the Kopf Family) KALAMAZOO, MI -- Abigail Kopf, the 14-year old shooting victim from the Feb. 20 shooting rampage in Kalamazoo, remains in critical condition Thursday, Feb. 25, at Bronson Methodist Hospital, said Carolyn Wyllie, spokesperson for the hospital. Kopf, of Battle Creek, was shot in the Cracker Barrel parking lot as she sat in a car with family friend Barbara Hawthorne, 68, Mary Jo Nye, 60, and Dorothy "Judy" Brown, 74, all of Battle Creek.The three women died, and so did a fourth member of their group, Mary Lou Nye, who was in another vehicle. A father and son were killed minutes earlier as they looked at cars in a lot, and Tiana Carruthers was shot, but not killed, in the parking lot of The Meadows townhomes in Richland Township earlier Saturday. Jason Dalton, 45, of Cooper Township, has been charged with all of the shootings. Rosemary Parker is a reporter for MLive. Contact her at rparker3@mlive.com. PENSACOLA NAVAL AIR STATION, Fla. – For nearly 15 years after the 9/11 terrorist attacks and more than eight years since the mass shooting at Fort Hood in Texas, Pensacola Naval Air Station has remained an unusually open U.S. military base — until now. The nation's first naval air station and home of the popular Blue Angels flight demonstration squadron this month has enacted strict new, permanent security measures intended to separate the nearly 1 million tourists who visit the base each year from the thousands of sailors, Marines and other military employees who work on the base. Security experts say the surprising thing is that base has remained relatively open for so long. "It appears they are late to the game on this," said Scott White, a professor of homeland security and security management at Drexel University in Iowa and former intelligence officer for the Canadian defense department. White said the previously open environment at the base is a rare reminder of different era. "Nowadays every military installation is a potential target as is anyone in a uniform," he said. Base officials say they have worked through the years to prioritize safety while accommodating the steady stream of tourists. But Cmdr. Shawn Dominguez, executive officer of the base, said the base had to align itself with Department of Defense security standards that physically separate tourists and other unauthorized visitors from military operations. Dominguez, who has been at the base for only a few months, said it was unusual that the public had become accustomed to relatively easy access there. "The base has been here for a long time and brings a tremendous economic benefit to the community," he said. "But I think everybody understands that in this security environment, the changes are necessary." The base now has separate entrance gates — one for military members and base employees and another for tourists and other visitors. The gates are about three miles apart. In the past, large warning signs made it clear that unauthorized people were not allowed on specific areas of the base and base security kept close watch on those areas. Under the new system, tourists will be denied access to military areas without passing internal guard booths and roadblocks. Visitors will also have to show identification and carry a visitor pass issued in their name. The pass must be presented to security officials at their destination. Anyone visiting military buildings or training areas must be issued a special visitor pass and be escorted. Thousands of tourists enter the base several mornings each week from March through October to watch the Blue Angels practice. The practices are often followed by pilot autograph signings inside the National Museum of Naval Aviation. Also located inside the base are two historic forts, which date to the late 1700s, a popular Civil War-era lighthouse, a sprawling military cemetery, an 18-hole military golf course and beach recreation area for active duty and retired military. Separating the tourists and recreational aspects of the base from its military operations has been complicated by the way the base is laid out with tourist and recreation areas near working military personnel, said Harold Saintcloud, the base's anti-terrorism and security officer. The Department of Defense media office declined comment on base security issues in a statement emailed to The Associated Press. The department also declined to comment on whether the situation at Naval Air Station Pensacola is unique because of the large number of tourists visiting the base each year. Retired Navy pilot Mikal "Butch" Kissick owns Wings Aviation, a military memorabilia and supply store just outside the gates of the Naval Air Station Pensacola. Kissick said his customer base is mostly Naval aviators who work on the base and that he isn't concerned about not having tourists passing by his store. "This was long overdue," he said. "I have often thought about how easy it was to get onto the base. They needed to tighten security." text: On Wednesday night, Excel Industries employee Brian Johnson got into a fight with co-worker Cedric Ford about "stupid stuff," mostly over Ford's fear that he was about to get fired. Johnson thought that they'd mend fences at work the next day. The two worked together at the lawn care company in Hesston, Kansas, but as Johnson's afternoon shift began, his friend was gone. The man told The Washington Post that he must have got to "pick up his guns, I guess." Around 5 p.m., the Kansas plant became the site of the country's 49th mass shooting. Johnson heard gunshots about that time and his boss yelled that someone had a gun. Later, co-workers said Cedric had been shooting at him -- but every bullet missed."Every foot track that I took he was right behind me, all the way through the plant."As he sat in a hospital in the small Kansas city, waiting to hear how his injured co-workers were fairing, he still couldn't understand why Cedric perpetrated the shooting, injuring 14 people and killing three. According to NBC News, the shooting lasted 26 minutes. It began when local police were dispatched to two eerily similar calls -- two people with gunshot wounds. The injured were shot in two separate nearby towns in this rural area of Kansas, 30 minutes from Wichita.Four People Killed, Including Gunman, 14 Others Injured In Kansas Shooting Rampage https://t.co/ox9pemFMVq pic.twitter.com/3UbGZNmdT4— BuzzFeed News (@BuzzFeedNews) February 26, 2016Multiple Deaths, Injuries in Kansas Shooting Spree https://t.co/rhiKzM3Jh1 pic.twitter.com/UKWvW2q0d7— The Voice of America (@VOANews) February 26, 2016The shooter fired at people from his car in the towns of Newton and Hesston, ABC News reported. He hit two vehicles first, injuring one person. Then he drove to a spot near the highway and shot another person in the leg. Four People Killed, Including Gunman, 14 Others Injured In Kansas Shooting Rampage https://t.co/ox9pemFMVq pic.twitter.com/3UbGZNmdT4 Multiple Deaths, Injuries in Kansas Shooting Spree https://t.co/rhiKzM3Jh1 pic.twitter.com/UKWvW2q0d7 He drove to his workplace next. He shot one person in the parking lot and was then seen by witnesses "entering the building with a long gun" before he "opened fire inside the building." An employee named Michael Dellinger, 20, described the scene inside. He and co-workers had just left a safety meeting when he heard a popping noise, which at first, he thought nothing of. But then he saw Ford standing in the doorway to the parking lot. And he was holding a gun. He immediately started shooting at the paint line."Then he turned toward our line. I grabbed the guy next to me and said 'Run, there's a gun.'"Everyone ran to the closest door. People were yelling around him, bullets pinging off factory equipment all around him. A fellow employee, Austin McCaskill, described the shooter as "running through the plant just going crazy with a gun … just randomly shooting people." The sheriff of this rural Kansas county, T. Walton, said that when police finally arrived on scene, Ford was "actively shooting at any targets that came into his sights."The first officer on scene went into the site of the active shooting alone. The officer, who's being called a hero and hasn't been identified, killed the gunman as he dodged a barrage of gunfire himself. The sheriff lauded the lone cop, who "saved a lot of lives." Five shooting victims are now in critical condition in local Kansas hospitals, one required surgery, and eight are in stable condition. For now, the sheriff's department have hinted that they've identified a motive for the shooting, and were quick to note it wasn't terrorism. After the shooting in this peaceful Kansas community, the gunman's criminal record and his co-workers' vague but pervasive feelings that something about was "real off" about him have come to light. Ford was a felon with a long criminal record, charged in 1996 with carrying a concealed firearm. He'd also been convicted on a number of charges in Florida, including burglary. Earlier this month, his live-in girlfriend accused him of assault. After he allegedly placed her in a chokehold, she told police he was an "alcoholic, violent, depressed" and "in desperate need of medical & psychological help!" Dellinger said staff at Excel have been talking about the shooting and the gunman's motive. He said the man gave him a "bad gut feeling." Whatever was going on, McCaskill didn't think it justified shooting people at work."He was having a bunch of problems. But you don't need to go blasting up a plant because you've got problems." [Image via Broward Sheriff's Office]
title: Kansas Shooting: Gunman Cedric Ford May Have Targeted Co-Worker

text:
HESSTON, Kan., Feb. 25 (UPI) -- At least three people were killed and 14 injured in a mass shooting Thursday at a Kansas facility that manufactures lawn care products, authorities said. The shooting occurred at about 5 p.m. at Excel Industries, located in the town of Hesston, north of Wichita, police said. Many of the 14 injured were in critical condition in local hospitals. About 150 people were working at the time of the shooting spree.
Advertisement The suspected shooter, identified as an Excel employee, was shot and killed by authorities. He used an assault rifle, perhaps a pistol as well, and appeared to have shot his victims at random, Harvey County Sheriff T. Walton said.
RELATED Missouri professor caught on camera cursing at journalists, police fired "I'm OK, the Lord took good care of me," a woman named Edna told KWCH-TV. She encountered the shooter as she was leaving the grocery store. The man got out of his truck and shot at her as he walked toward her car. She said she escaped by quickly putting her car in reverse. A co-worker at the facility said he was unloading pallets in the back of the building when he heard "a pop, pop."
Advertisement "We thought it was just metal falling on the ground, and then the doors opened, people started screaming, coming out," a co-worker named Dylan, who still had blood on his hands from trying to help a shot co-worker, told KSNW. "We really didn't know what was going on."
RELATED Protester confronts Clinton, demands apology for mass incarceration Hesston College was placed on lockdown due to what police called an "active shooter" event. The Wichita TV station also reported a different shooting in the town of Newton, but it wasn't immediately known whether it was related to the incident at Excel. Excel manufactures "turf care" products, such as lawnmowers.

Thanks for contacting us. We've received your submission. News By Fox News Submit February 26, 2016 | 9:14am Mississippi Gov. Phil Bryant declared April Confederate Heritage Month on a pro-Confederate website, following a path similar to other states’ in the past. Bryant’s proclamation was posted to the Mississippi Sons of Confederate Veterans website, but not to the governor’s site. He signed it days before legislators killed bills that would have either removed the Confederate battle emblem from the 122-year-old state flag or stripped money from colleges and local governments that refuse to fly the current banner. The Jackson Free Press, a weekly newspaper, first reported the proclamation Wednesday and noted that other Southern state governors have passed similar proclamations. Georgia designates each April as Confederate History and Heritage Month. The paper noted that the Sons of Confederate Veterans group is against the changing of the Mississippi flag and “pushes a revisionist history about the Civil War.” Clay Chandler, a spokesman for Bryant, said previous governors, Democrat and Republican, have issued similar proclamations for Confederate Heritage Month. “Gov. Bryant believes Mississippi’s history deserves study and reflection, no matter how unpleasant or complicated parts of it may be,” Chandler said. “Like the proclamation says, gaining insight from our mistakes and successes will help us move forward.” Symbols of the Confederacy have come under fire since the mass shooting at a Charleston, S.C., church last June. Dylann Roof was charged in the killings and had been seen posing for photos online holding a Confederate flag. After the shooting, South Carolina lawmakers and Gov. Nikki Haley removed a Confederate battle flag that had flown for years on the Statehouse lawn. Also since the attack, several Mississippi cities and counties, and some universities, have stopped flying the state flag, which is the last in the nation to feature the Confederate emblem — a red field topped by a blue X dotted with 13 white stars. Democratic state Rep. Ed Blackmon, a member of the Mississippi Legislative Black Caucus, said he has no problem with people honoring Confederate ancestors. “But, at the same time, I would hope the governor would consider that people have problems with the Confederate flag,” Blackmon said. Blackmon said he grew up seeing the flag used by the Ku Klux Klan as a symbol of racial oppression. He said: “That’s a part of history you cannot deny.” The Associated Press contributed to this report. text: Gallery: Several people dead in multiple Kalamazoo County shootings Andrew Jamieson of Jamieson Fabrication Unlimited in Richland. Jamieson was best man in Jason Brian Dalton's wedding and said it "doesn't seem real" that the friend he's known for 26 years could have shot eight people in a shooting spree that police say targeted random people. (Mark Bugnaski/Kalamazoo Gazette) KALAMAZOO, MI -- To friends, Jason Dalton was a good family man, who usually avoided confrontation, had been a good high school football player and was good at what he did, whether it was taking exams for his law enforcement degree or performing auto body work. They are in disbelief that their friend can be the man accused of shooting eight people, killing six of them, in a random shooting spree in Kalamazoo. The best man in Jason Dalton's 1995 wedding said it "doesn't seem real" that the friend he's known for 26 years could have shot eight people in a shooting spree that police say targeted random people. Andrew Jamieson said the allegations are "very much out of character" with the man he knew. They had stayed close up until they drifted apart in the past 15 years as their families' grew. They last spoke about a year ago. "But as things are coming out in the news, there are a lot of things I obviously didn't know about," he added. Dalton, 45, of Cooper Township, is the suspect in a Feb. 20 mass shooting that killed six, injured two and spanned three shooting scenes across Kalamazoo County. Police say the gunman chose his victims at random, and say they still do not have a motive for his crimes. Several riders have come forward to say Dalton served as their Uber driver before, between and after the shootings across Kalamazoo County. Jamieson said he didn't know Dalton had recently started driving for Uber. In high school, Dalton was a varsity football co-captain, graduating in 1989 from Comstock High, just east of Kalamazoo. Before attending Comstock schools, Dalton grew up in Greenfield, Ind., where he attended Eastern Hancock middle and high schools. A teacher and coach in the Eastern Hancock district described Dalton as an "average student and promising athlete" who participated in the school's football, wrestling and track programs, according to the Daily Reporter in Greenfield, Ind. Jamieson said he met Dalton 26 years ago at a party when they were 18. The men bonded over common interests such as working on cars and riding dirt bikes. Jamieson helped them move into their house on Douglas Avenue in Cooper Township, and was Dalton's best man in their 1995 wedding. Jamieson said that after about 12 years of their friendship, they grew apart as Dalton and his wife started a family and Jamieson started his own business. Dalton was someone who would be cordial to people, but who wasn't outgoing, Jamieson said. "He wouldn't go out of his way to make friends with people," Jamieson said. Dalton and Jamieson would occasionally go out and shoot targets or clay pigeons. "I never once was ever concerned about going out and shooting targets or clay pigeons, that he would turn it on me or someone else," Jamieson said. Jamieson said he was surprised to hear police had removed 15 guns from Dalton's house since he never knew Dalton to have "more than a couple" guns. "Not that I would ever expect him to turn them on someone," Jamieson said. "It was never like that." In fact, Jamieson said, it seemed to be the opposite. Dalton had gotten his law enforcement degree at Kalamazoo Valley Community College and was looking for a job as a police officer in the early 1990s. Jamieson said Dalton couldn't find a job as a police officer in Michigan or in nearby states, and he wasn't interested in moving far away for a police job. Instead, Jamieson said, he went to school for auto body work at WyoTech in the state of Wyoming, and was hired at BMW North American in New Jersey. Jamieson said he did well on everything, whether it was the law enforcement exams or auto body work. In his late 20s, Dalton got into insurance, and Jamieson said knowing auto body work helped him in his new profession. He held down jobs at State Farm and Progressive insurance companies, and eventually went to work for himself as an independent insurance adjuster who worked on contract for other companies. He was out on a work appointment about a year ago when he stopped into Jamieson's shop in Richland. "That's last time I had seen him face-to-face or spoken to him," Jamieson said. One neighbor who declined to give his name because of the barrage of media attention following the shootings, said Dalton "is a good family man. He's a good man. That's all I'll say." Cooper Township Supervisor Jeff Sorensen said everyone in the small township is shocked. "Everybody that I talked to that knew him or knew of him couldn't believe that this is the person who committed this heinous activity." Mark Cottingham, owner of Visions Custom Cars & Trucks, told a Kalamazoo Gazette reporter he and Dalton bumped heads last September over an estimate Cottingham provided to a customer for repairs to a Kia Optima. Dalton said the job was worth less than Cottingham's estimate. The two squabbled in person and Dalton got into a screaming match with the owner of the car, Cottingham said. Cottingham said the shop's estimate prevailed. On his last visit to the shop, Dalton's demeanor had changed and he was more pleasant, said Cottingham and mechanic Wade Phillips. But Cottingham said he was curt and dismissive in a final phone call when told of the additional repair costs. "He is the only guy whose boss I've called in 20 years and said, 'This guy is not representing you well,'" Cottingham said. He said he was shocked to turn on the news Sunday morning and see Dalton's face. "I hadn't heard anything that happened, and I go, 'It's that insurance adjuster. I wonder what he did? Cottingham said. "And then it showed the story and I said, Oh, my goodness." After watching the report, he said, "Man, I'm glad I wasn't on his list." Sorenson recognized Dalton as the insurance adjuster who reviewed hail damage on his pickup truck last September. "It wasn't until Sunday that it clicked that it was him," Sorensen said. Jamieson said he and his wife were eating dinner at Martini's Saturday evening when they saw police lights race by the restaurant. About midnight, someone at the restaurant announced there was a man on the loose who had shot at least six people. "I just thought, you know, another nutcase," Jamieson said. Jamieson said the next morning he started getting text messages from people wanting to know if it was true that Dalton was the suspect. "I flipped on TV and there was Jason sitting there in a jumpsuit," Jamieson said. "It just doesn't seem real." Jamieson said he and Dalton had talked about people who committed mass murders as unstable. "We used to talk about people that did that (committed mass murders), loose cannons. "Jason would walk across the street to avoid trouble," Jamieson said. "Literally. He was just not interested in confrontation at all." While Jamieson stressed that he hadn't talked to Dalton in a while and didn't know of any recent stressors in his life, he said when they talked regularly he knew Dalton's marriage to be as normal as "any mid-American marriage." "They didn't jet set, they weren't high rollers. They would go to work, come home, do their thing," Jamieson said. The couple has a 15-year-old son and a daughter who's 10, Jamieson said. Jamieson said when they last talked, they talked about how Jamieson's business was going well, and how Dalton's daughter liked to help him work on cars. Jamieson said he has reached out to Dalton's parents, but hasn't heard back from them. He said Dalton's parents encouraged their only child work for anything he wanted. "I believe they instilled good value in him," Jamieson said. "They're good, hearty people. They were always kind to me, always kind to all of Jason's friends." Jamieson said he doesn't feel like he has a lot to offer to help people understand why Dalton could have gone on a shooting spree. "I was the one getting in all the scuffles," Jamieson said. "He was the one hiding behind the car. It just blows my mind." Jamieson said the crime is unfair to the victims and their loved ones. "Those people aren't coming back and that's so unfair," Jamieson said. "Nothing from here on out could bring them back and that's permanent. That's the absolute worst." Emily Monacelli is a reporter for MLive.com. Contact her at emonacel@mlive.com or follow her onTwitter. text: President Barack Obama on Friday offered condolences to the families of the victims of Thursday’s mass shooting shooting in Hesston, Kansas. Speaking at an event in Jacksonville, Florida, Obama noted that the shooting came just days after another mass shooting in Kalamazoo, Michigan, and called on lawmakers to prioritize action on gun control. “These acts may not dominate the news today, but these are two more communities in America that are torn apart by grief,” Obama said. “We cannot become numb to this.” Three people were killed and 14 others were injured after a gunman, whom police identified as Cedric Ford, opened fire in three locations, including the Excel Industries plant where he worked. The President said he called the mayor of Hesston, David Kauffman, Friday morning to express his condolences. Obama emphasized that the issue of gun violence was not getting the attention that it deserved and had “become routine.” He also implored the media to keep reporting on stories about gun violence. “I hope the media pays attention to this,” he said. “Once a week we have these shootings. And it doesn’t dominate the news and that has to change.” Watch below via ABC News:  Planned Parenthood is leaving the federal government’s Title X program, which funds family planning services for low-income people, due to… Following the ousters of the Homeland Security secretary and Secret Service director, and the withdrawal of the would-be ICE director’s… Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) on Monday called for ousted Secret Service Director Randolph “Tex” Alles to testify before… Non-members are still able to read comments, but will no longer be able to participate. text: President Obama implored the media to pay more attention to mass shootings Friday, saying "the real tragedy is the degree to which this has become routine." Obama's remarks at a Florida battery factory were his first public remarks since a a shooter opened fire in a lawn mower parts factory in Hesston, Kansas Thursday, killing three people and leaving 14 wounded. "I hope all of you pay attention to this. I hope the media pays attention to this. Once a week we have these shootings, and it doesn't dominate the news. And that's got to change," Obama said Friday at an event in Jacksonville, Fla. intended to highlight the success of his 2009 economic stimulus plan. “As long as I hold this office I’m going to keep on bringing this up, even if it's not getting the attention that it should. And I wish I didn't have to keep on talking about it. Lord knows I wish I didn’t have to make these phone calls and comfort families," he said. USA TODAY Woman charged with providing guns to Kansas shooter Earlier, Obama called Hesston Mayor David Kauffman while flying to Florida from Air Force One. The White House said the president offered his condolences for the victims and his gratitude to the off-duty police officer was first on the scene and acted quickly to save lives. The Hesston shooting, Obama noted, follows the Kalamazoo, Mich. rampage last week that left six people dead. “These acts may not dominate the news today but these are two more communities in America that are torn apart by grief. And I thought it was important for me to say something today because somehow, as I've said before, this becomes routine," Obama said. "We cannot become numb to this." It's not the first time Obama has challenged the news media to pay more attention to gun violence. After a shooting at an Oregon community college last October, he asked news organizations to "tally up the number of Americans who’ve been killed through terrorist attacks over the last decade and the number of Americans who’ve been killed by gun violence, and post those side-by-side on your news reports." He also said he would speak out on every mass shooting and pledged to "politicize" the issue until Congress passed gun control legislation.
title: Obama: Mass shootings should dominate the news

text:
Gallery: Several people dead in multiple Kalamazoo County shootings KALAMAZOO, MI - The wife of mass-shooting suspect Jason Brian Dalton has filed for divorce. Carole Dalton filed for divorce in Kalamazoo County Circuit Court after her husband allegedly went on a shooting spree on Saturday, Feb. 20, that left six dead and two seriously injured. The couple married in 1995. Dalton's family had earlier released a statement: "There are no words which can express our shock and disbelief, and we are devastated and saddened for the victims and the families of the victims. "We cannot comprehend the grief which you are feeling, and, while it seems woefully inadequate, we are deeply sorry and are praying for everyone affected." The Daltons have two children, ages 15 and 10.
Carole Dalton is seeking sole custody of the children and child support from her husband's 401k plan. The filing said that "there has been a breakdown in the marriage relationship to the extent the objects of matrimony have been destroyed and there remains no reasonable likelihood that the marriage can be preserved." Jason Dalton was earning $50,000 a year at Michigan Appraisal Company and also worked as an Uber driver. Dalton, 45, is facing six counts of murder, two counts of assault with intent to commit murder and eight counts of felony firearm use. Police say he randomly shot people in Kalamazoo County. Abigail Kopf, 14, of Battle Creek, was critically wounded. She was shot as she sat in a car outside of a Cracker Barrel restaurant. Three others in the vehicle were killed: Barbara Hawthorne, 68, Mary Jo Nye, 60, and Dorothy "Judy" Brown, 74, all of Battle Creek. A fourth member of their group, Mary Lou Nye, who was in another vehicle, also died. Tyler Smith, 17, and his father, Rich Smith, 53, were killed as they looked at cars at Seelye Automotive on Stadium Drive. Tiana Carruthers survived being shot while in the parking lot of The Meadows townhomes in Richland Township while trying to protect children in the area. A motion for temporary custody and child support that accompanied the divorce complaint asks for Carole to be granted custody of the children, with no "temporary parenting time" awarded to Jason Dalton. text: Trending: In a voice thick with emotion, one of Orange County’s most prolific jailhouse informants begged a judge for leniency Friday, citing his work against former associates in the Mexican Mafia prison gang. Fernando Perez, an inmate at the center of Orange County’s snitch controversy, faces a possible sentence of 25 years to life for a “third-strike” conviction on a gun charge. “This is the single most important day in my life,” Perez told Superior Court Judge Gregg L. Prickett. “I want anyone I ever affected (to know) I am deeply and sincerely sorry.” Perez, 34, once known by the nickname Wicked, said he began working as a jail informant for federal and local agencies in an effort to secure his freedom. “I have changed beyond words and now have the opportunity to make something amazing out of my life,” he said. The former member of Santa Ana’s 18th Street gang found himself suited for snitch work, with his ability to feign empathy for fellow gang members and other inmates. He then wrote nightly notes to his jail handlers, titling them “Operation Daylight.” Related: Go ‘Inside the Snitch Tank’ in our special section In October 2011, Perez befriended Seal Beach mass shooting suspect Scott Dekraai shortly after his arrest, calling Dekraai “bro” and bringing him hot water to make tea, according to documents filed by Dekraai’s attorney. Perez encouraged Dekraai to open up, as jailers secretly recorded more than 100 hours of their conversations. In court Friday, Assistant U.S. Attorney Joe McNally called Perez’s work as a jail informant “critical” in destroying the hold of the Mexican Mafia in Orange County’s jails. Perez’s testimony against a top Mexican Mafia leader and 100 other gang members has led to a series of convictions “like dominoes falling,” McNally said. Judge Prickett listened as local and federal prosecutors and an FBI agent praised the informant for nearly an hour in his packed Santa Ana courtroom. Prickett described the case as “unique.” He then postponed sentencing to Friday. The current case against Perez stems from his 2007 arrest for being a felon in possession of a firearm. In a separate case, from a 2006 arrest, he is charged with methamphetamine possession. Perez’s rap sheet also includes convictions for robbery, gun charges, possession of a stolen vehicle and enhancements for being a gang member. He has been jailed in Orange County for about eight years. According to court documents, Perez’s tenure as an informant almost ended before it began around 2001. His confidential informant card contains the notation, by an Anaheim detective: “Terminated as a CI. Do not use.” Perez was caught keeping a gun at his home. Around 2009, Perez – a rising Mexican Mafia member – took another shot at working as an informant after his conviction in the third-strike gun case. The prosecutor on the case presented Perez to a jury as a liar and a hardened criminal. Later, after Perez became an informant, the same prosecutor described Perez in a future court appearance as a credible informant who turned his life around, according to court records. During his time behind bars, Perez provided information about pending attacks on jail inmates and sheriff’s deputies, saving about 11 people from being hurt or killed, his defense attorney, Richard Curran said in a court motion. Perez also gathered incriminating statements in 2010 from community theater actor Daniel Wozniak, who was awaiting trial on double-murder charges. The following year Dekraai, the Seal Beach shooter, landed in a cell next to Perez after Dekraai’s arrest on charges of killing eight people at a hair salon. Assistant Public Defender Scott Sanders, who represents Wozniak and Dekraai, accused prosecutors of planting Perez next his clients in violation of constitutional law and then hidingevidence about his role. Prosecutors later agreed not to use evidence gathered by Perez in the two cases. The District Attorney’s Office also has said it would not seek any consideration from the judge for Perez on those two cases. Sanders has spent two years compiling and leveling allegations that police and prosecutors systematically used a network of jailhouse snitches on inmates who already had lawyers and then withheld evidence on those informants. After two lengthy hearings on Sanders’ motions, Superior Court Judge Thomas Goethals in March removed the District Attorney’s Office from the Dekraai case, a ruling that is under appeal. Dekraai has pleaded guilty to the shootings; his penalty phase trial has been delayed indefinitely. For his efforts working with local police and federal agents, Perez has earned a place on the Mexican Mafia’s death or “hard candy” list, prosecutors said in court Friday. The informant is now in federal protective custody and will spend whatever sentence he is given looking over his shoulder, prosecutors said. “If you rat, you’re dead,” Deputy District Attorney James Laird told the judge. On Friday, Perez said he has risked his life to cooperate with the government and would like consideration for those efforts. “I no longer chose the easyway,” he said. “I chose the way less taken while others sit back and wait for their release.” Staff Writer Kelly Puente contributed to this report. text: HESSTON, KAN. — Authorities say a woman has been charged with providing firearms to the gunman who killed three people and injured several others at a factory in Kansas. Prosecutors announced Friday that 28-year-old Sarah T. Hopkins was charged with one count of knowingly transferring a firearm to a convicted felon. She's accused of giving two weapons to Cedric Ford, who was fatally shot by police during the Thursday shootings at Excel Industries in Hesston. An affidavit says the Newton woman gave Ford a Zastava Serbia, which is an AK-47-type semi-automatic rifle, and a Glock Model 22 40-caliber handgun. Prosecutors say Hopkins knew Ford wasn't allowed to have a firearm because he was a felon. Ford was killed during a shootout with the police chief in Hesston, a town about 30 miles north of Wichita, after opening fire Thursday at the Excel Industries lawnmower parts plant where he worked, authorities said Friday. Ford also shot and wounded two people from his car as he drove to the site. Harvey County Sheriff T. Walton said earlier Friday that Hesston's police chief, Doug Schroeder, was a "tremendous hero." Walton said between 200 and 300 people were in the factory at the time, and the "shooter wasn't done by any means when Schroeder chased and shot him. "Had that Hesston officer not done what he did, this would be a whole lot more tragic," Walton said. Authorities identified the dead as 44-year-old Brian Sadowsky of Newton; 31-year-old Josh Higbee of Buhler; and 30-year-old Renee Benjamin, whose hometown wasn't immediately available. All three victims worked at the plant and were killed inside the building. Walton said his office served Ford with a protection-from-abuse order at around 3:30 p.m. Thursday, about 90 minutes before the first shooting happened. He said such orders are usually filed because there's some type of violence in a relationship. He did not disclose the nature of the relationship in question. Authorities on Friday said Ford had a history of domestic violence, including an arrest in Newton in November 2008 for felony battery and disorderly conduct. He also was arrested in July 2010, for driving while intoxicated and obstruction. The shooting came less than a week after a man opened fire at several locations in the Kalamazoo, Michigan, area, leaving six people dead and two severely wounded. Authorities have not disclosed a possible motive in those attacks. The suspect remains in custody.Associated Press CONNECT TRIBUNE PUBLISHING COMPANY INFO Copyright © 2021, Chicago Tribune
title: Woman charged with providing guns to Kansas mass shooting suspect

text:
HESSTON , Kan., Feb. 27 (UPI) -- A Kansas woman was charged with giving weapons to Cedric Ford, the gunman who was responsible for the mass shooting at a lawn mower parts plant on Thursday. Ford's ex-girlfriend Sarah Jo Hopkins, 28, was charged with transfer of a firearm to a prohibited person on Friday. An affidavit states that she transferred a Zastava Serbia AK-47 and a Glock Model 22 .40-caliber handgun to Ford while knowing he was a convicted felon.
Advertisement The weapons were the same ones used when Ford shot 17 people at Excel industries before being killed in a shootout with police on Thursday. Hopkins told the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives she bought the guns at a pawn shop in 2014 and kept them at a home she and Ford shared for a period of time. She then moved out of the shared residence in July 2015 and left the guns with Ford, despite being aware of his criminal history. She was able to get the weapons back with police help, but returned them to Ford in August 2015 after he threatened her. Hopkins could face up to 10 years in federal prison and a fine of $250,000 if convicted.

Max Levchin, the Affirm CEO and Paypal founder, was interviewed by Charlie Rose Friday night and shared a somewhat surprising stance on Apple’s legal battle with the FBI. Levchin said he wants Apple to help government officials gather data from a locked iPhone that was used by terrorists responsible for a mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif., back in December. This is the opposite viewpoint of many of Silicon Valley’s other prominent tech leaders, including Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Google CEO Sundar Pichai. “I ultimately hope that this propels its way to the Supreme Court very quickly, and the Supreme Court actually tells Apple, ‘You are compelled to open this phone up,’ Levchin said during the interview. “I personally want to see this case in front of the FBI with every bit of evidence so that they have access to whatever information they need to make sure my kids are safe.” Buuut … there’s a catch. Levchin wants Apple to help just this once, and has a plan for how to avoid setting a precedent for companies breaking through their own security measures at every government request. It hinges on the recent death of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia and the unusual political situation his absence causes. “We have a four against four court, which means it doesn’t set precedent,” he explained. “The court can compel Apple to open this one phone, and then it still goes in front of Congress. And we still have the public debate, and we still fundamentally decide what society would want to be.” Well. That’s one scenario. text: This article originally appeared on PEOPLE.com. Hollywood A-listers will be supporting more than their favorite films on Sunday at the Academy Awards. Patricia Arquette, Steve Carell, Bryan Cranston, and others will add a specific piece of jewelry to their wardrobes for the night, as they promote a campaign against gun violence in the United States. “This awards season, the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence is teaming up with Hollywood to lift up the stories of the 90 Americans killed every day by gun violence,” a press release from the campaign states. “On the red carpet, high-profile celebrities … will join the effort to shed light on the human cost of gun violence by wearing unique, hand-crafted bracelets that commemorate Americans killed or injured by gun violence.” The bracelets – decorated in a simple black and gold design – are a part of Brady’s #ENOUGH campaign which encourages celebs and other influencers in the entertainment industry to call attention to the “critical need” to stop gun violence. (For more information, go to SayEnough.org.) The Brady campaign advocates a specific background check that prevents “convicted felons, domestic abusers, and fugitives” from owning the weapon. It also remembers victims whose lives were cut short by gun violence. Watch the PEOPLE & EW Red Carpet Live streaming pre-show celebration on Feb. 28 beginning at 5:30 p.m. ET/2:30 p.m. PT on PEOPLE.com and EW.com, with live red carpet coverage, fashion and beauty trends, and winner predictions. Seeing the bracelets on the red carpet will certainly be a poignant reminder of Thursday’s mass shooting in Kansas, which left four dead, including the gunman, and 14 injured – just months after the terrorist shooting in San Bernardino left 14 dead. As gun violence has continued to be an sensitive issue in America, many stars have made it a point to be vocal with their opinions about gun laws in the country. At the New York premiere for her film Jane Got a Gun in January, Natalie Portman told PEOPLE that she was “very concerned” about the issue, and even admitted to being nervous about working with the weapon for the movie. text: SEATTLE — A coroner in Washington state on Saturday released the identity of a gunman and three of his four victims in what authorities described as a mass shooting and suicide. David Wayne Campbell, 51, shot and killed himself Friday in front of police who said they tried for more than three hours to get him to surrender, said Mason County Coroner Wes Stockwell. In an outbuilding on the remote, wooded property near Belfair, southwest of Seattle, authorities found four bodies, including those of his wife of six years, Lana J. Carlson, 49, and her sons, Quinn Carlson, 16, and Tory Carlson, 18. Stockwell withheld the identity of the fourth victim pending notification of relatives. On Friday morning, Campbell called a police officer he knew and reported that he had shot his family. The officer traveled across Puget Sound from Seattle and responded to the home, as did a Mason County SWAT team. For 3½ hours, a deputy sergeant tried to persuade the man to surrender, but he finally walked outside and shot himself, the Sheriff's Office said. A 12-year-old girl was able to escape the house. She was taken to a hospital but had not been shot, authorities said. "Apparently she's okay," Chief Deputy Ryan Spurling said. "I don't know if this is a daughter, or stepdaughter, or what the relationship is, but she escaped from the house." Jack Pigott, who lives down the road, said he heard gunshots Thursday night but none Friday. Campbell and Carlson were married in November 2009, King County records show. The wife had two teenage sons who were adopted from Russia during a previous marriage, Pigott said, as well as a daughter who was adopted from China. Her first husband died of cancer, he said. Campbell ran a business called Campbell Family Heating and Air Conditioning, according to state records, while Carlson — who also went by Lana Jane Campbell — had registered a business called Crispy Edges. She had purchased a food truck, and she and Campbell had been working on it. The neighbor also said Campbell had recently been hospitalized, but he didn't know why.
title: Wash. gunman killed wife, stepsons, 1 more

text: Gallery: Family and friends honor Tyler and Richard Smith in memorial at Seelye KALAMAZOO, MI -- After a memorial service was held for Richard and Tyler Smith Saturday afternoon, hundreds more gathered late Saturday evening for another tribute. Seelye Auto Group moved vehicles to clear space for friends and family of the father and son to commemorate their lives, at the spot where a week earlier a gunman ambushed them. Their deaths were among six within a span of less than 20 minutes, as Jason B. Dalton allegedly went from the Seelye lot on Stadium Drive to the Cracker Barrel on Ninth Street and shot to death four women the night of Feb. 20. "Emily (Smith, the daughter of Richard and sister of Tyler) requested a candle-lit ceremony and to let balloons go up in the air with written messages on them at 10:05 p.m., at the exact time this community and family lost two amazing people," Mickey Seelye, general manager and part-owner of Seelye Auto Group, stated in a Facebook post. After hundreds of balloons were released into the air by the crowd, fireworks illuminated the night sky, a reminder that life can be beautiful even in the darkest of times. text: Gallery: Family and friends honor Mary Jo Nye at memorial service BATTLE CREEK, MI -- A weekend of memorial services and celebrations of the lives of those slain in Kalamazoo's mass shooting closed Sunday as hundreds gathered to remember Mary Jo Nye. "My time with Mary Jo has been only three years, but I count every minute of it a blessing," Pastor Chad Parmalee of Chapel Hill United Methodist Church said to open Sunday afternoon's service there. Nye was killed in a Feb. 20 shooting spree in Kalamazoo County that claimed six lives, including her sister-in-law Mary Lou Nye, of Baroda. "Celebration seems a difficult thing to even contemplate today, but a life lived the way Mary Jo's life was lived calls for celebration," Parmalee said Sunday during a service of scripture and song. Mary Jo Nye, 60, was born to Charles Manley and Joan (Cushing) in 1955 and with her six siblings lived on the family farm in Baroda, sharing chores, picking fruits and vegetables for market, and doing what kids do -- playing in tree forts, sledding down hills, running through the fields and making up games as they went. She grew fond of Lake Michigan. "Mary Jo's love for the big lake began early in life and never faded. She loved Lake Michigan, she loved the shoreline. It brought her peace," the pastor said. "Mary Jo said that whenever she saw the lake, she was reassured that things would just be okay." She learned to cook, can and bake and to sew, quilt and knit from her mother and her grandmother, retaining that touch throughout her life and becoming known for her gifts of fresh-baked bread, cookies and handmade quilts. But she will remembered most for her dedication to learning. She taught English at Calhoun Community High School, "Mary Jo knew reading was the key to success and made it her life's work to insure that whenever possible, the people she encountered could read and could write," Parmalee said. As a teacher, "she had a knack for investing in children's lives in a way that made learning a contract between them. Her students knew that it wasn't a give-only kind of situation -- it was a give-and-take, back-and-forth exchange of information and relationship and trust. "She found a way to teach even the kids who were the hardest to reach. Mary Jo could love them into learning." But she too was a demanding, straight-forward mentor who gained the respect of her students by helping them learn to respect themselves, Parmalee said. During Sunday's service, students of Nye's shared their memories of her. One recalled how at 15 or 16 she cared little about applying herself at school, cutting class and showing up late, until Nye intervened. "She picked me up every day and brought me to school, and I drove her crazy because I was always late coming out. She always told me, 'I'm not gonna pick you up anymore if you can't be on time,' but she always came back," Nye's former student recalled. "She practiced what she preached. She taught me that there were people who cared, and that I needed to care, too." Chuck Crider, former executive director of Calhoun Community High School, talked about how Nye's influence on students transcended the classroom. "It was more than teaching. It was bringing things in from home for kids to wrap for Christmas to take to their families because they might not have anything," he said. "The teaching was a given. The thing that sticks in my mind is that she touched lives -- she took kids outside of the classroom and challenged them to be their best." One former student shared how he hadn't turned in a paper before graduation, and though he was passing the class, Nye wasn't going to let him graduate. As he walked at commencement, he was handed a piece of paper. To get his diploma, he'd have to turn in that paper, which he did three weeks later. "She did that because she knew I could do better," he said. "She was pushing me to be my best." Parmalee, in closing the service, said of Nye: "She challenged the people she knew, and in doing so, challenged the people she didn't. This can be a better world, with more people who can read, more people who have faith in themselves, more people who believe that there can be more by not giving up." "It would be a travesty," he concluded, "for us to walk into this room, tell all these nice stories and then do nothing when we left. Let her life be an inspiration to you. If you can read, you can teach someone to read." Chelsea Purgahn is a multimedia specialist for MLive. Follow her on Instagram and Twitter, and email her at cpurgahn@mlive.com. text: As its senator is forced to fight his presidential opponent over his record on gun control, the New England state is home to a push to educate sellers Last modified on Wed 5 Jun 2019 09.17 BST When Vermont considered tightening its gun laws last year, hundreds of citizens wearing hunter orange showed up at the state house to protest.  Bernie Sanders’ home state has some of the most gun-friendly laws in the nation. It also has the nation’s lowest violent crime rate. The push to require universal background checks on gun sales failed almost immediately. But gun rights advocates didn’t stop with defeating background checks legislation. Vermont had only six gun murders in 2014, but according to statistics from the FBI and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, it had 59 gun suicides. “We do have a small problem with suicides in the state. It’s not huge, like the anti-gunners say, but it is a problem,” said Ed Cutler, president of Gun Owners of Vermont, which labels itself a “no-compromise” gun rights organization. At the same time as they fought back against new regulations, Cutler and other gun rights leaders proposed a different approach: educating gun owners about suicide risk and how to de-stigmatize seeking mental health treatment. A year later, the state affiliate of the National Rifle Association and Gun Owners of Vermont are rolling out a program to bring suicide awareness to gun stores, ranges, and clubs. They will also host training on how to talk to friends in crisis about getting help. “This is not an anti-gun or a veiled anti-gun campaign – this is strictly us helping ourselves,” said Chris Bradley, president of the Vermont Federation of Sportsmen’s Clubs, Vermont’s state NRA group. Experts from the state’s department of mental health have worked closely on the project, but gun rights groups are leading the public outreach. They have vetted every poster and fact sheet to make sure the suicide prevention message is not mixed with anti-gun rhetoric. It is a very different approach from the fight over gun laws and gun industry regulation that has become a key part of the presidential battle between Sanders and Hillary Clinton, in which Vermont will vote this week, as one of the potentially crucial Super Tuesday primaries. Nationwide, gun suicides represent nearly two-thirds of annual gun deaths. Public mass-casualty shootings like the ones this past week in Hesston, Kansas, and Kalamazoo, Michigan, represent only a tiny fraction of the overall toll. Nationwide, the group most at risk for gun suicide are white, middle-aged men. While gun homicide rates have remained mostly flat since 2000, gun suicide rates are rising. About half of America’s gun suicides involve a firearm, a means of suicide that is almost always lethal. Studies have found that many people act within less than an hour of deciding to kill themselves – and some within minutes of the decision. While people some who survive a suicide attempt will try again, 90% will not ultimately die from suicide. For many, a suicidal crisis can be very brief. That means, researchers say, that finding ways to limit people’s access to firearms in the midst of that crisis could be a key factor in saving lives. Educating gun dealers to look for signs of suicide risk is one line of defense. But many Americans most at risk already own guns. The approach being tested in Vermont is whether more education about suicide risk might persuade some gun owners to let their friends keep their guns for them when they’re experiencing depression or going though a divorce, a job loss, or another difficult time. “A lot of our members, they’re terrified they’re going to have their guns taken away,” said Cutler, the Gun Owners of Vermont president. He said he believes the focus on using laws to disqualify people with mental health problems from owning guns ends up discouraging gun owners from seeking mental health treatment at all. Taking a friends-helping-friends approach will work better, he said. “We can hold their guns for them, talk to them, get them counseling, and once it’s over and done with, we’ll give them their guns back and there won’t be stigma attached. “Gun owners trust gun owners.” Clinton, who has emphasized her willingness to go after the gun lobby to help prevent gun violence, has said very little about suicide. Her campaign policy page on gun violence prevention notes that “about 33,000 Americans are killed by guns each year” but does not mention that roughly 20,000 of those deaths are suicides. Her list of strategies to prevent this “unacceptable” death toll makes no mention of suicide at all. A campaign spokeswoman said Clinton’s support for expanding background checks and federal research on gun violence would help to reduce suicide, as would her support for improving existing laws focused on prohibiting people “suffering from severe mental illness from purchasing or possessing a gun”. The spokeswoman cited a study from the gun control group Everytown for Gun Safety that found dramatically lower rates of gun suicide in states that require background checks for all handgun sales than in states that do not. But the study does not control for rates of firearm ownership. In an academic study that found a correlation between tough gun laws and lower rates of gun death, when the researchers controlled for the number of guns in a state, the link “essentially disappeared”. A spokesman for Sanders’ campaign touted the senator’s past efforts to expand mental health access, especially for veterans at risk of suicide, and pointed to his single-payer health insurance plan, designed to provide access to mental health services to all Americans. He also cited Sanders’ support for improving the nation’s background check system for firearm purchases. Sanders’ approach to gun policy has long stayed in line with that of his rural state, which has high rates of gun ownership and strong support for gun rights even among Democratic leaders. When universal background checks were debated last year, Vermont’s Democratic governor said he thought the state’s laws were perfectly adequate. Over the past few months, as Clinton has continued to hammer him on guns, Sanders has moved towards more gun control-friendly positions. Clinton has hit hardest on Sanders’ vote in favor of a 2005 federal law that protects firearm manufacturers, distributors and dealers against lawsuits over the criminal misuse of their products. In January, Sanders told reporters that he would cosponsor a bill to repeal this gun industry shield law. A repeal of the law could open up a new series of lawsuits by gun control groups seeking to hold firearms manufacturers and distributors responsible for monitoring whether their products end up in the hands of people with criminal records. In Vermont, the suicide prevention effort also focuses on gun dealers, but organizers are appealing to empathy and moral responsibility, not legal liability. Bradley, the president of the Vermont Federation of Sportsmen’s Clubs, said most gun sellers he knows have had the experience of selling a gun to a customer who later used it to kill themselves. “To say it weighs heavily on someone is a horrible understatement,” he said. On Friday, Bradley brought a stack of suicide prevention materials to a gun dealer in Barre, just south of Vermont’s capital, Montpelier. Rather than having the state’s department of mental health deliver the posters and fact sheets, gun owners are doing all of the delivery and education themselves. It gives credibility to the campaign, Bradley said – and makes it clear the materials are a service gun advocates are providing, rather than another mandated requirement from the state. At R&L Archery, a large, family-run outdoor goods store, Bradley waited while Jon Sanborn, the store’s vice-president, finished with a customer who would need to update his address on his ID before he could pass a background check. Then he spread out the campaign’s new posters on the counter and made his pitch. “The whole idea is to establish a dialogue,” he said. “I’m not a psychologist and you’re not a psychologist.” “Clearly,” Sanborn broke in, drily. Sanborn said he liked the materials designed to educate store employees about being watchful for signs of suicide. But he did not have a positive reaction to the poster designed to reach people at risk of suicide, which had “Thinking about suicide?” in red letters at the top. “I don’t love that for the front of my store,” he said. Ninety-nine percent of his customers, he said, would not be associating buying a gun with suicide, and he did not want to put that thought in their heads. But he said he did support the broader project of putting more focus on suicide prevention. “There’s never been any awareness on our end,” he said. “Warning signs – things to look for, that kind of thing, none of that has propagated through the gun world.” Most people have some kind of personal connection to gun suicides, Sanborn said, as well as knowing that they have sold a few guns to people who have used them to kill themselves. “It does cast the rest of our industry and the rest of our hobbies in such a negative light,” he said. “Any of the political speeches you look at – Hillary Clinton had one at the end of last year – 92 people a day are killed by firearms, and if you look at the number, those are true, but 60-some odd of those 90 are suicide.” He said the Vermont Gun Shop project was the first initiative he had seen to actually work through firearm dealers to tackle that problem. On Saturday, at the Snowsville General Store in Randolph, store owner Eugene Booska also said he was willing to participate in the new suicide prevention program, though he had not seen the new materials yet. Booska’s store stocks milk and eggs as well as guns, and is heated by an old-fashioned wood-burning stove. “They asked me if I would support, to help to pass out information,” Booska said. “I think it’s fine, and I will pass it out. I don’t know as it’s going to work very well.” Choosing not to sell one gun to someone who seems at risk might not prevent them from killing themselves, he said. “Most guys that I sell guns to have already got a lot of guns.” Booska’s wife, Kris, said she has sometimes trusted her gut instinct and refused to sell someone a gun, even if they have passed a background check. Firearms dealers always have the option to refuse a sale. But she also remembers selling a gun to someone who later killed himself, and she did not see any red flags. She remembers him talking about the death of his dog, and comforting him, but: “I did not have any inkling that he intended to kill himself.” If I’d been educated about what to look for, perhaps I would have seen something more that I didn’t see. Or if, you know, I had like a script of something you might say to somebody.” Vermont’s suicide prevention program is modelled on that of New Hampshire. In 2009, one New Hampshire gun store had three customers buy firearms and use them to kill themselves within the space of a week. The gun store owner began to work with public health experts to figure out what his store might have been able to do differently to prevent this tragedy. The result was the New Hampshire Gun Shop project, rolled out in 2011, which educates gun store employees about signs of suicide risk and how to use casual conversation with customers to check for red flags, as well as using gun stores as a place to spread public awareness about gun suicide and ways to get help. A study of the project found roughly half of gun stores in New Hampshire were displaying program materials. The ultimate effect of the effort on suicide rates has yet to be measured. But according to Cathy Barber, the director of the Means Matter suicide prevention campaign at the Harvard School of Public Health, variations of the New Hampshire model are being tested in at least 14 states, including Vermont. Ten more states are in early stages of developing the program, she said. Because gun owners and their families are affected by suicide at higher rates than non-gun owners, taking an anti-gun approach to suicide prevention is, as Barber often puts it, “like sending an anti-gay group to do a suicide prevention campaign in the gay and lesbian community”. Vermont’s leading gun control group does back the new suicide prevention campaign. Ann Braden, the head of Gun Sense Vermont, said she was delighted when she heard Cutler bring up the New Hampshire Gun Shop Project at a state hearing. “It was like the world had become all sparkly,” she said. Her group will continue to push for a state universal background check law in 2017, she said. But she added that it was “very refreshing” to have her gun rights opponents working on a prevention program of their own, “rather than a no to everything”.
title: Vermont gun lobby bypasses Sanders v Clinton in attempt to cut down suicides

text:
Watch CBSN Live  February 29, 2016 / 8:18 AM
          / CBS/AP KALAMAZOO, Mich. - The condition of a 14-year-old girl is improving, more than a week after she survived a mass shooting in Kalamazoo, Michigan. Vickie Kopf posted an update about her daughter on Facebook. She says Abigail Kopf's ventilator was removed Sunday and that she's breathing on her own. Abigail was outside a Kalamazoo-area restaurant when she was shot in the head on Feb. 20. Six people were killed - four at the restaurant and two at a car dealership. Another victim shot at an apartment building survived. Jason Dalton is charged with murder and attempted murder. Funerals and memorial services were held over the weekend. The last was held Sunday at a Battle Creek church to honor Mary Jo Nye, a retired teacher who was killed at the restaurant. Kopf was initially believed to have been killed in the shooting. Michigan State Police say she was a passenger in a car Mary Jo Nye was driving. Vickie Kopf said Barbara Hawthorne, another passenger in the car who was killed, was a grandmother figure to Abigail, and the pair were regularly hanging out together. Abigail's heart beat stopped during initial attempts to save her life, but it was restored. An organ donation service was contacted with her parents' permission, though she was never declared medically brain dead. Her parents were making arrangements to donate her organs when the girl squeezed her mother's hand. Kopf told CBS affiliate WWMT the sensation of having her hand squeezed was "breathtaking." "They then called in the doctor and he asked her a question and wanted a thumbs-up in response," state police said last week. "And she gave him two thumbs up. It's a glimmer of hope in this otherwise tragic situation." The Battle Creek Community Foundation is accepting donations to help the Kopf family cover medical expenses. text: The 14-year-old Michigan girl who was shot in the head and nearly died in the Kalamazoo shootings is now breathing on her own, her mother said. Abigail Kopf’s ventilator was removed on Sunday, and she was able to wipe her own face, her mother, Vickie Kopf wrote on Facebook. The update comes more than a week after a gunman killed six people and wounded two others at random. Authorities initially believed the teenager had been killed after she and four other people were shot outside a restaurant on Feb. 20. Her parents were making organ donor arrangements when Abigail miraculously squeezed her mother’s hand, according to the CBS News. Last week, Michigan State Police Lt. Dale Hinz told the AP that the girl later gave her doctor two thumbs up. “It’s a glimmer of hope in this otherwise tragic situation,” he said at the time. Contact us at letters@time.com.

February 29, 2016 A high-profile fatal shooting of a civilian woman and a female police officer in northern Virginia this weekend offers a glimpse into one of the most common, and one of the least common, forms of gun death in the United States. Army staff sergeant Ronald Hamilton has been charged with killing his wife and Prince William County police officer Ashley Guindon, who was on her first day on the job. Mr. Hamilton, who worked at the Pentagon, has been charged with capital murder, first degree murder, and malicious wounding. Prosecutor Paul Ebert said he will likely seek the death penalty. The incident began on Saturday night when Hamilton got into an argument with his wife. She called 911, he fatally shot her, and he then began firing on the officers who responded to the call. Officer. Guindon died from injuries sustained in the shooting, the police department said, and two other officers were wounded. Within the larger national debate over gun violence in America, the case encapsulates two of the higher-profile forms of fatal shooting: that of an intimate partner, and that of a police officer. From 2006 to 2014 an average of 554 American women where fatally shot by romantic partners, according to an Associated Press analysis of FBI and state crime data, roughly one every 16 hours. Seventy-two percent of all murder-suicides in the US involve an intimate partner, according to the National Coalition against Domestic Violence, and 94 percent of the victims in murder-suicides are female. In 2015, the most common type of mass shooting involved the shootings of family members, according to a recent Monitor analysis. Meanwhile, some law enforcement officials have claimed that police officers are increasingly targets for violence. Citing FBI statistics showing that the number of officers "feloniously killed" jumped from 27 in 2013 to 51 in 2014 – the year the Black Lives Matter movement rose to national prominence protesting fatal police shootings around the country – some officials have blamed what they describe as anti-cop rhetoric from the movement for an uptick in violence against police. "At any point where the rhetoric ramps up to the point where calculated cold-blooded assassination of police officers happen[s], this rhetoric has gotten out of control," said Harris County (Tex.) Sheriff Ron Hickman, after Darren Goforth, one of his deputies, was shot and killed in an ambush attack in August. But a broader look at statistics reveal that the increase in police deaths isn’t that alarming in context. The 23 officers murdered in 2013 made it the safest year for police officers in recorded history, said Seth Stoughton – a former police officer and an assistant law professor at the University of South Carolina – in an interview with NPR. In fact, 2015, the same year Officer Goforth was killed, was the second safest year for police officers, according to the Officer Down Memorial Page, which tracks all police deaths. Material from The Associated Press was used in this report. Already a subscriber? Login Monitor journalism changes lives because we open that too-small box that most people think they live in. We believe news can and should expand a sense of identity and possibility beyond narrow conventional expectations. Our work isn't possible without your support. Already a subscriber? Login   Link copied. Dear Reader, About a year ago, I happened upon this statement about the Monitor in the Harvard Business Review – under the charming heading of “do things that don’t interest you”: “Many things that end up” being meaningful, writes social scientist Joseph Grenny, “have come from conference workshops, articles, or online videos that began as a chore and ended with an insight. My work in Kenya, for example, was heavily influenced by a Christian Science Monitor article I had forced myself to read 10 years earlier. Sometimes, we call things ‘boring’ simply because they lie outside the box we are currently in.” If you were to come up with a punchline to a joke about the Monitor, that would probably be it. We’re seen as being global, fair, insightful, and perhaps a bit too earnest. We’re the bran muffin of journalism. But you know what? We change lives. And I’m going to argue that we change lives precisely because we force open that too-small box that most human beings think they live in. The Monitor is a peculiar little publication that’s hard for the world to figure out. We’re run by a church, but we’re not only for church members and we’re not about converting people. We’re known as being fair even as the world becomes as polarized as at any time since the newspaper’s founding in 1908. We have a mission beyond circulation, we want to bridge divides. We’re about kicking down the door of thought everywhere and saying, “You are bigger and more capable than you realize. And we can prove it.” If you’re looking for bran muffin  journalism, you can subscribe to the Monitor for $15. You’ll get the Monitor Weekly magazine, the Monitor Daily email, and unlimited access to CSMonitor.com. Subscribe to insightful journalism Less noise. More insight. Follow us:
